msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21 US District Court Western Division of Washington, Seattle

div1.p: In the United States District Court, for the Western District of Washington Northern Division
In the matter of Ching Hing
#2857 Interrogatories to be propounded to Corry M. Stadden, Attorney of Washington, D. C.
1. What is your name and occupation?
2. Did your firm act as attorneys for Ching Hing, in his case with the United States Government?

3. Did you visit the building in which the business of the Secretary of hte Department of Labor is transacted, on September 24th, 1914, September 25th, 1914, and September 26th, 1914, or on either of said dates?
4. If so, were Secretary Wilson or Assistant Secretary Post, or either of them, present in the Department of Labor on said dates, or on either of said dates?

5. Do you know when the affirmation of the decision of the Commissioner of Immigration in ruling the deportation in Ching Hing, was made by J. B. Densmore, assuming to act a as "Acting Secretary" of Labor?

6.If so, on said date, do you know of your own knowlegde that Secretary Wilson or Assistant Secretary Post, or either or both of them were present in the Department of Labor on that date on which said decision was affirmed by said J. B. Densmore, assuming to act as "Acting Secretary" of Labor?

7. Do you know of any ruling made by the Federal Court in any District, holding that J. B. Densmore has not the authority in law or in fact to act as Secretary of the Department of Labor when either Secretary Wilson or Assistant Secretary Post, or either of them are present in the Department of Labor?
8. If you answer the above question in the affirmative, state what Federal Court has so ruled on this question, and what the decision was?
